title: 110_s2784
content: The Act may be cited as the Howard M. Metzenbaum "Menu Education and Labeling Act" or the "MEAL Act". Congress acknowledges the strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the rise in obesity in the United States, where 2/3 of American adults are overweight or obese according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Obesity also increases the risk of diabetes and heart disease. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals prepared or eaten outside the home, with 1/3 of calories and almost half of total food dollars spent on food purchased or eaten. The annual cost of obesity in the United States is $117 billion, with obesity increasing the risk of diabetes, heart disease, stroke, cancer, and other health problems. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and almost half of total food dollars spent on restaurant food. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States, costing the economy an estimated $142 billion in 2005. Heart disease is a leading cause of disability among working adults in the United States, costing the economy $142 billion in 2005. Increased sodium intake is linked to high blood pressure, which can lead to cardiovascular disease. The proportion of adults with high blood pressure increases with age. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires food manufacturers to provide nutrition information on packaged foods. About 75 percent of adults use food labels on packaged foods, which is linked to eating more healthfully. The proportion of adults with high blood pressure increases with age. "Restaurant foods are exempt from nutrition labeling requirements unless a health claim is made. 75 percent of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Limited availability of nutrition information at restaurants makes it hard for consumers to control calorie intake." Consumers struggle to limit calorie intake at restaurants due to lack of nutrition information. Studies suggest providing nutrition information at the point of sale can help consumers make informed decisions. Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend increasing access to nutrition information to reduce obesity. The Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend increasing access to nutrition information to reduce obesity. SEC. 3. NUTRITION LABELING OF STANDARD MENU ITEMS AT CHAIN RESTAURANTS. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include exceptions for restaurants and retail food establishments in the nutrition labeling of standard menu items at chain restaurants. Restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name must disclose nutrition information for standard menu items, with exceptions for certain types of food. Restaurants with 20 or more locations under the same trade name must disclose calorie and fat information for menu items. Restaurants with 20 or more locations must display calorie, fat, and sodium content of standard menu items in a clear manner as specified by the Secretary. Restaurants with 20 or more locations must display calorie content of standard menu items in a clear manner as specified by the Secretary. Restaurants with 20 or more locations must display calorie content of standard menu items in a clear manner as specified by the Secretary. The calorie information must be provided in writing upon request of a prospective purchaser. This requirement does not apply to items not listed on a menu. Restaurants with 20 or more locations must provide calorie content of standard menu items in writing upon request of a prospective purchaser. This requirement excludes items not listed on a menu, daily specials, temporary menu items, or self-service food sold at salad bars or buffet lines. Restaurants with 20 or more locations must provide calorie content of standard menu items in writing upon request. Self-service food sold at salad bars or buffet lines must have a sign listing calories per serving. Retail food establishments, including restaurants, can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. State or local regulations can also require restaurants to provide nutrition information. State or local regulations can require restaurants to provide nutrition information in addition to federal requirements. The Secretary must propose regulations within one year of enactment to implement these requirements. The Secretary must propose regulations within one year of enactment to implement requirements for nutrition information in restaurants. After enactment, regulations allowing for variations in serving sizes and food preparation must be promulgated, with final regulations to be implemented within two years. The Secretary must propose regulations within one year of enactment for nutrition information in restaurants. Final regulations must be promulgated within two years, or proposed regulations will become effective. Final regulations under item (III) must be finalized within 2 years of enactment. Proposed regulations for vending machines will become effective on the day after that date. The Secretary will publish notice of the final regulations in the Federal Register. Final regulations for vending machines, applicable to operators with 20 or more machines, require a conspicuous sign for food items that cannot be examined before purchase. The final regulations for vending machines mandate that operators with 20 or more machines must display a sign disclosing the calorie content of food items. Vending machine operators are also allowed to provide additional nutrition information voluntarily. The regulations allow vending machine operators to voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. State or local requirements do not prevent vending machine operators from providing extra nutrition information. The Secretary must propose regulations within one year and finalize them within two years of this clause's enactment. The Secretary must propose and finalize regulations within two years of the clause's enactment. Failure to do so will result in the implementation of proposed regulations. If the Secretary does not finalize regulations within 2 years, proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations.
